title: Cancer Genetics: Precision Oncology
description: Human Genetics : The past, present, and future of cancer research and treatment with an emphasis on precision medicine driven by significant advances in genomics. Precision medicine uses genomics, RNA and protein abundance, as well as key metabolic and physiological markers to best design and implement treatment.

title: M.Sc. Thesis Research 1
description: Human Genetics : Independent research work under the direction of the Thesis Supervisor and the Supervisory Committee.

title: M.Sc. Thesis Research 2
description: Human Genetics : Independent research work under the direction of the Thesis Supervisor and the Supervisory Committee.

title: M.Sc. Thesis Research 3
description: Human Genetics : Independent research work under the direction of the Thesis Supervisor and the Supervisory Committee.

title: M.Sc. Thesis Research 4
description: Human Genetics : Independent research work under the direction of the Thesis Supervisor and the Supervisory Committee.

title: Inherited Cancer Syndromes
description: Human Genetics : The principles and practice associated with inherited predisposition to cancer (breast and colon cancers, example) such as the methods of gene discovery, clinical characteristics of inherited predisposition, methods of mutation analysis, genetic counselling, and ethical issues of genetic testing.

title: Human Genetics
description: Human Genetics : This course will emphasize the principles and practice of human genetics, including an overview of the fundamental aspects of human genetics pertaining to chromosomes and mutations, population, cancer and development genetics, the inheritance of complex traits.

title: Using Bioinformatics Resources
description: Human Genetics : Study of internet resources relevant to biomedical research.

title: Psychiatric Genetics
description: Human Genetics : A seminar on current knowledge in the field of complex trait genetics as it applies to psychiatric disease.

title: Advanced Readings in Genetics 1
description: Human Genetics : A review and discussion of specific topics in genetics (genetic models: population-based, animal, and in vitro genetic models, genomics, and medical genetics) centred on current literature and latest advances in the field.

title: Advanced Readings in Genetics 2
description: Human Genetics : A review and discussion of specific topics in genetics (genetic models: population-based, animal, and in vitro genetic models, genomics, and medical genetics) centred on current literature and latest advances in the field.

title: Advanced Readings in Genetics 3
description: Human Genetics : A review and discussion of specific topics in genetics (genetic models: population-based, animal, and in vitro genetic models, genomics, and medical genetics) centred on current literature and latest advances in the field.

title: Advanced Readings in Genetics 4
description: Human Genetics : A review and discussion of specific topics in genetics (genetic models: population-based, animal, and in vitro genetic models, genomics, and medical genetics) centred on current literature and latest advances in the field.

title: Ph.D. Comprehensive Examination
description: Human Genetics : An examination that must be passed by all doctoral candidates in order to continue in the doctoral program.

title: Kyoto-McGill Ph.D Seminar
description:
Human Genetics : Required for Kyoto-McGill Ph.D. students. Coordinated in conjunction with the Human Genetics Senior Seminars, students will present a research seminar of their major thesis research, prior to initial thesis submission and as a
requirement for graduation.

title: FYS: Hispanic Literature and Culture
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Introduction to major issues in Hispanic literature and culture through the analysis of primary and secondary sources and intensive writing.

title: Portuguese Language: Beginners
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : A comprehensive first-year course in speaking, reading and writing. Selected readings in Portuguese and Brazilian literature.

title: Portuguese Language: Intermediate
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Review of grammar. Practice in speaking and writing. Composition. Selected readings in Portuguese and Brazilian literature.

title: Spanish Language: Beginners
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : A comprehensive first-level course focusing on all oral and written skills. An introduction to the fundamentals of Spanish grammar and syntax and to Hispanic culture.

title: 1 Spanish Language: Beginners
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : A comprehensive first-level course focusing on all oral and written skills. An introduction to the fundamentals of Spanish grammar and syntax and to Hispanic culture.

title: 2 Spanish Language: Beginners
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : See HISP 210D1 for course description.

title: Spanish Language Intensive - Elementary
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : A comprehensive first-level course focusing upon all oral and written skills. An introduction to the fundamentals of Spanish grammar and syntax and to Hispanic culture.

title: Spanish Language Intensive - Intermediate
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : A thorough review of Spanish grammar with emphasis upon current usage. Enrichment of all language skills, with a goal of proficiency in written and oral communication, through readings in the literature and civilization of Spain and Spanish America.

title: Spanish Language: Intermediate
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : A thorough review of Spanish grammar with emphasis upon current usage.  Enrichment of all language skills, with a goal of proficiency in written and oral communication, through readings in the literature and cultural aspects of Spain and Spanish America.

title: 1 Spanish Language: Intermediate
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : A thorough review of Spanish grammar with emphasis upon current usage. Enrichment of all language skills, with a goal of proficiency in written and oral communication, through readings in the literature and civilization of Spain and Spanish America.

title: 2 Spanish Language: Intermediate
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : A thorough review of Spanish grammar with emphasis upon current usage.  Enrichment of all language skills, with a goal of proficiency in written and oral communication, through readings in the literature and cultural aspects of Spain and Spanish America.

title: Hispanic Civilization 1
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : A survey of historical and cultural elements which constitute the background of the Hispanic world up to the 18th century; a survey of the pre-Columbian indigenous civilizations (Aztec, Maya and Inca) and the conquest of America.

title: Hispanic Civilization 2
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : A survey of the constitution of the ideological and political structures of the Spanish Empire in both Europe and America until the Wars of Independence; a survey of the culture and history of the Hispanic people from the early 19th Century to the present.

title: Survey of Spanish Literature and Culture 1
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : From the origins to the Golden Age through a study of representative works.

title: Survey of Spanish Literature and Culture 2
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : From the Golden Age to the modern period through a study of representative works.

title: Survey of Latin American Literature and Culture 1
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : From the Colonial period to Modernism through a study of representative works.

title: Survey of Latin American Literature and Culture 2
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : From Modernism to the present through a study of representative works.

title: Hispanic Literature and Culture in English 1
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : A topic in the literatures and/or cultures of the Hispanic world will be studied, with all readings and discussion in English.

title: Contemporary Brazilian Literature and Film
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : This course introduces students to Brazilian literature and film from the early 20th century to the present day. Students will examine literary works and films from a historical perspective, studying the social, political and regional processes in which they are embedded. From the barren Northeast, to an analysis of gender and race, to urban violence and its manifestations to the contemporary cityscape, this course covers a range of visual and textual material. Students will engage works from major Brazilian authors and filmmakers in conjunction with theoretical texts to better understand some of the main developments in contemporary cultural production.

title: Hispanic Literature of the 18th Century
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : A critical study of neo-classical drama and poetry; satirical prose; Jovellanos, Iriarte, Moratín and others.

title: Spanish Novel of the 19th Century
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : The Romantic, Realist and Naturalist novel in Spain, with special emphasis on the development of the Spanish novel in relation to contemporary trends in other European countries.

title: Spanish Romanticism
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : The aesthetic and historical development of Romanticism, with special emphasis on lyric poetry and drama.

title: Literature of Ideas: Latin America
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Critical reading and discussion of works of outstanding thinkers as a key to understanding the cultural development of a continent.

title: Latin American Literature of 19th Century
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : An intensive study of representative authors from the period of Independence to the advent of Modernism.

title: Theatre, Performance and Politics in Latin America
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : A study of the outstanding works of the theatre from the colonial period to the present, including pre-Columbian works.

title: Latin American Cinema
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : A study of representative films, directors and movements of the region. Topic specified by instructor.

title: Spanish Cinema
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : A study of representative films, directors and movements of the region. Topic specified by instructor.

title: Contemporary Hispanic Cultural Studies
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : This course examines contemporary Hispanic Cultural Studies looking at both cultural artifacts and diverse theoretical and methodological approaches. In doing so, it will introduce students to the frameworks necessary for approaching contemporary culture in the Hispanic World. The course will be mindful of issues including ideology, class, race, ethnicity and sexuality. Students will come into contact with the major cultural theorists in the Hispanic World and those issues pertinent to the study of culture.

title: Queer Iberia
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : This course explores queerness as identity, aesthetics, and theory in Iberian society and culture—literary, visual, audial, and digital. Readings will include cultural texts, performances, theoretical works by major queer and gender theorists, and case studies. The goal of this course is for students to gain a critical understanding of queerness as form, theory, and practice, through the lens of Iberian cultural production.

title: Latin American Novel
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Critical reading and discussion of contemporary Spanish-American fiction writers.

title: Contemporary Spanish Literature and Culture
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : An interdisciplinary study of the literary, visual, and digital cultures of contemporary Spain, particularly in its post-authoritarian era (since 1975). Students will also be exposed to critical theory and social and political debates relevant to the course material and its context.

title: Latin American Short Story
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Study of style, tendencies and types as reflected in the evolution of this genre, and seen against the background of a developing continent.

title: Latin American Digital Literature and Culture
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : This course will examine digital cultural production in Latin America from 1990 to the present day. This course introduces students to theoretical frameworks necessary for approaching new media and web-based cultural artifacts, both literary and visual. Students will come into contact with the major writers, artists and web-based cultural producers in Latin America and issues pertinent to the study of the Web in the region.

title: Gender and Textualities
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Historical development and literary tendencies regarding gender and sexuality in Hispanic literature, film, and culture.

title: Literature - Discovery and Exploration Spain New World
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : A study of the primary literary and intellectual developments stemming from Spain's discovery of the Americas. Special attention will be given to the changing perception of the New World's natural resources and indigenous peoples as this is reflected in the literature of the period.

title: Colonial / Postcolonial Latin America
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : A study of the dialogue between colonial and postcolonial Latin American texts and theories.

title: Topics: Spanish Literature
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Specific topics of interest in Spanish literature.

title: Topics: Latin American Literature
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Specific topics of interest in Spanish-American literature.

title: Don Quixote
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Course on the canonical work by Cervantes, Don Quixote. The course will focus on the first modern novel as well as on a number of critical readings.

title: 20th Century Latin American Poetry
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : A study of representative trends and authors (Darío, Martí, Huidobro, Mistral, Vallejo, Neruda, Paz).

title: Major Figures: Spanish Literature and Culture
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Specific figures of interest in Spanish literature.

title: Major Figures: Latin American Literature and Culture
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Specific figures of interest in Spanish-American literature.

title: Medieval Literature
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : A study of important works of the period: Poema de Mio Cid to La Celestina. Given in alternate years.

title: Golden Age Literature: Renaissance
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : A comprehensive examination of the poetry, prose and drama of the Renaissance in Spain through representative authors.

title: Tutorial 01
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Individualized guided research on an approved topic in Hispanic Studies.

title: Honours Thesis
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Under the direction of a staff member, students prepare the honours thesis on a theme in Hispanic Studies.

title: 1 Honours Thesis
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Under the direction of a staff member, students prepare the honours thesis on a theme in Hispanic Studies.

title: 2 Honours Thesis
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : See HISP 490D1 for course description.

title: Internship: Hispanic Studies
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Internship with an approved host institution or organization.

title: Seminar in Hispanic Studies 01
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : A team-taught seminar examining major issues in Hispanic letters that transcend national literatures and historical periods. Although the specific topics will vary, each will address broad questions of a diachronic nature, thereby permitting an understanding of literary schools and movements, genres or ideologies present throughout the Hispanic world.

title: Research Project Methodology
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Preparatory work towards the production of the two guided research papers.

title: Culture and Literature
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Investigation of principal themes and critical issues in culture and literature of Spain and/or Latin America.

title: Literature of Ideas
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Investigation of principal themes and critical issues in the literature of ideas of Spain and/or Latin America.

title: Pre-1800 Literature and Culture
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : A guided research paper on a selected topic in pre-1800 literature and culture of the Iberian Peninsula and/or Latin America under the supervision of a faculty member.

title: Modern and Contemporary Iberian Literature and Culture
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : A guided research paper on a selected topic in Iberian literature or culture from 1800 to present under the supervision of a faculty member.

title: Modern & Contemporary Latin American Literature and Culture
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : A guided research paper on a selected topic in Latin American literature or culture from 1800 to present.

title: Spanish Theatre: Golden Age
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Investigation of principal themes and critical issues in the Spanish theatre of the Golden Age.

title: Spanish-American Prose
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Investigation of topics in Spanish American prose.

title: Special Topics 1
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Special topics seminar on Hispanic leterature and culture.  Topics may vary by year.

title: Special Topics 2
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Special topics seminar on Hispanic leterature and culture.  Topics may vary by year.

title: Special Topics 3
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Special topics seminar on Hispanic leterature and culture.  Topics may vary by year.

title: Special Topics 4
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Sepcial topics seminar on Hispanic literature and culture.  Topics may vary by year.

title: Special Topics 5
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Special topics seminar on Hispanic leterature and culture.  Topics may vary by year.

title: Thesis Preparation 1
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Preparatory work towards the Mater's thesis.

title: 1 Thesis Preparation 1
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Preparatory work towards the Master's thesis.

title: 2 Thesis Preparation 1
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : See HISP 695D1 for course description.

title: 1 Thesis Preparation 1
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Preparatory work towards the Master's thesis.

title: 2 Thesis Preparation 1
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : See HISP 695N1 for course description.

title: Thesis Preparation 2
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Preparatory work towards the Master's thesis.

title: M.A. Thesis
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Written presentation of the thesis to the research supervisor(s).

title: 1 M.A. Thesis
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Written presentation of the thesis to the research supervisor(s).

title: 2 M.A. Thesis
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : See HISP 697D1 for course description.

title: Reading Course 1
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Supervised reading course.  Topics chosen to suit individual interests.

title: Ph.D. Comprehensive Examination
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Ph.D. Comprehensive examinations, both oral and written.

title: Research Seminar
description: Hispanic Studies (Arts) : Doctoral-level research seminar exploring a variety of research topics.

title: FYS: Jewish Concepts of Others
description: History : A survey, using translated primary and selected secondary sources, of the ways in which Jews represented Christians from late antiquity to the present. Legal, liturgical, literary and other sources are examined with the focus on the Medieval and Early Modern periods.

title: FYS: Sources of World History
description: History : An introduction to the constitutive intellectual traditions of world history.

title: FYS: Race in Latin America
description: History : This seminar explores what it meant to be native, black, or white in Latin America from the colonial period to the present. It explores how conceptualisations of race and ethnicity shaped colonialism, social organisation, opportunities for mobility, visions of nationhood, and social movements.

title: FYS: Nation Building and Nationalism
description: History : An introduction to some of the major theories of nationalism; an exploration of the many varieties of nationalism and forms of nation-building; a particular focus on the historical background to case studies of current interest.

title: FYS: History
description: History : An introduction to the discipline of history through an in-depth look at a selected topic.

title: Introduction to African History
description: History : This course stresses the interactions of the peoples of Africa with each other and with the worlds of Europe and Islam from the Iron Age to the European Conquest in 1880.

title: Modern African History
description: History : While covering the general political history of Africa in the twentieth century, this course also explores such themes as health and disease, gender, and urbanization.

title: Survey: Canada to 1867
description: History : A survey of early Canada, from periods known mainly through archaeological records to the Confederation era. Social, cultural, economic and political themes will be examined.

title: Survey: Canada since 1867
description: History : A survey of the development of Canada from Confederation to the present day. Social, economic and political history will be examined in a general way.

title: Ancient Mediterranean History
description: History : An introduction to the history of the ancient Mediterranean world, focusing on Greek and Roman civilization.

title: Indian Ocean World History
description:
History : An introduction to the “global” system connecting eastern Africa, the Middle East,
South and Southeast Asia, and the Far East, from the earliest times to c. 1900.

title: Jewish History: 400 B.C.E. to 1000
description: History : An overview of Jewish history from the period of Ezra and Nehemiah to the death of Hai Gaon, c. 1035. Focus on the experience of the Jews in Hellenistic and Islamic civilizations. Topics include Jewish sects, rabbinic literature in its various genres, the Karaite schism, and the rise of the Gaonate.

title: Introduction to East Asian History
description: History : An introduction to the history of East Asian civilization from earliest times to 1600, with emphasis on China and Japan, including social, intellectual, and economic developments as well as political history.

title: Introduction to South Asian History
description: History : Charts the making of South Asian civilization, 2500 BCE- 1707 CE, through a selection of key themes and major trends. Focus on the transformation of local kinship ties into regional kingdoms and empires, the evolution of religion and the legacy of the expansion of Islam and consequent rise of Turkish, Afghan and Mughal empires in this area.

title: Introduction to Latin American History
description: History : Historical development of Latin America’s peoples through the pre-Columbian, colonial and national periods, c. 1300-2000. Introduces key historiographical debates of the subfield and emphasizes the interpretation of primary source texts (in translation).

title: American History to 1865
description: History : Introduction to the history of colonial North America and the United States up to the Civil War, in their Atlantic context.

title: Medieval Europe
description: History : An introduction to the history and culture(s) of Europe in the Middle Ages.

title: World History, 600-2000
description: History : A thematic and comparative approach to world history, beginning with the rise of Islam and ending with globalization in the late twentieth century. Trade diasporas, technology, disease, and imperialism are the major themes addressed.

title: Early Modern Europe
description: History : Survey of European history from the Late Middle Ages to the eighteenth century.

title: Modern Europe
description: History : Survey of European history from the eighteenth century to the present.

title: Introduction to Russian History
description: History : The longue durée of Russian history from its origins in Kievan Rus and the Rurik dynasty, through the Romanov dynasty, the Soviet period, and post-Soviet developments.

title: Modern East Asian History
description: History : An introduction to the history of China and Japan from the seventeenth century to the present, including modernization, nationalism, and the interaction of the two countries.

title: Jewish History: 1000 - 2000
description: History : The Jewish experience from the rise of the European centres to the present.

title: United States since 1865
description: History : Examines the defining moments and movements in the U.S. since Reconstruction, including populism, progressivism, the World Wars, the New Deal, the Cold War, the sixties and its consequences. Emphasis on the political, social and ideological transformations that ensued.

title: History of Pandemics
description: History : A regional perspective (based on responsible instructor) to explore relevant pandemics over the long term, introducing the broader historical trends and impacts. The hidden dynamics of social, cultural, legal, and intellectual history while also helping us cope with current and future pandemics reasonably and responsibly. While providing basic medical and epidemiological information, its primary focus falls on the social and political contexts for--and responses to--each pandemic covered.

title: Indigenous Peoples and Empires
description: History : History of Indigenous Peoples of North and South America and their early experiences of European conquest and colonization, c. 1400 - 1800.

title: Introduction to the African Diaspora
description: History : African history is global history. Introduction to African civilizations, starting in the medieval period, the emergence of proto-Black racial consciousness, colour/race prejudice and anti-blackness, institutions of resilience (such as spiritual systems and kinship networks), enslavement in North Africa, Mediterranean, Levant, Arabia, Indian Ocean, and Americas, and revolutionary resistance against racial tyranny.

title: East Central and Southeastern Europe in 20th Century
description:
History : Introductory survey of east central and southeastern European history from the twilight of nineteenth-century imperialism to the most recent expansion of the
European Union. Consideration will be given to the two world wars and their consequences; nationalism, fascism, and socialism; and the revolutions of 1989.

title: Histories of Science
description: History : An introduction to the history of science, with attention to conceptual development and to institutional and social settings. Coverage will vary by instructor, but will include a range of periods (from antiquity to the 20th century), geographical settings, and themes (e.g. instrumentation; visualisation; experiment; science and society).

title: Modern History of Islamic Movements
description: History : Islamic revival in the Middle East which led to the rise of different versions of Islamic traditions and beliefs. Emphasis on the nature and character of leading nationalist and Islamic movements and their ideologues since the late 19th century.

title: Health and the Healer in Western History
description: History : The natural history of health and disease and the development of the healing arts, from antiquity to the beginning of modern times. The rise of "western" medicine. Health and healing as gradually evolving aspects of society and culture.

title: Making Great Britain and Ireland
description: History : Survey of the development of the multinational state in the British Isles and Ireland from antiquity to the seventeenth century revolutions. Emphasis on state making and ethnicity formation in England, Ireland, Scotland and Wales, as well as English overseas territories in Europe, Africa, and the Americas.

title: Mediterranean and European Interconnections
description: History : Introduction to the cultural practices and political experiences that have shaped the Eastern Mediterranean and South-Eastern Europe examined diachronically. Topics adressed include empires and nations, religion, politics of memory and space, archeology and historical legacies, migrations.

title: Ancient Roman History
description: History : A survey of Roman history from the foundation of Rome to the fall of the Roman Empire.

title: History and the Environment
description: History : Sketch of the history of the material aspects of human interaction with the rest of nature. Included will be a historian's view of the social, technical, and ecological implications of the great variety of activities devised by our species. Though global in outlook, this course will emphasize the relevant historiography of France, England and North America.

title: Topics in History
description: History : An introduction to a topic or theme in History.

title: The Historian's Craft
description: History : Introduction to the discipline of history. What is history? Where is history done? How is history done? Why do history? Historical writing is emphasized. Recommended for history majors.

title: History of Law and Society
description: History : The history of practices, ideas, philosophies of law in society, from Antiquity to the 21st century, including western and non-western legal traditions, in relation to property, crime and violence, slavery and liberty, constitutionalism and internationalism, and the environment.

title: U.S. Mass Media
description: History : Surveys the history of American mass media. It covers the rise of various communications technologies and genres within national and transnational contexts and interrogates the relationship between media, politics, culture, identity, and power.

title: International Relations History 1: 1750-1950
description: History : The history of international relations during the era of the four global wars, the expansion of the West in world affairs, the changes in the balance of power in Europe, the rise and fall of the colonial empires, and the ascendancy of the flank powers, Russia and the United States.

title: History of Quebec
description: History : Covering Quebec history from New France to contemporary times, this course will include themes like ethnic relations, citizenship, gender and material culture. It is of particular interest to students in Education who foresee teaching about Quebec.

title: International Relations History 2: Cold War
description: History : The history of the Cold War. Special attention will be paid to the different viewpoints and experiences of the Cold War participants by studying the historiography and archival materials released in the Eastern Block and Western World.

title: East Central Europe, 1944-2004
description:
History : An examination of important problems in the postwar history of east central Europe. Topics include: the establishment of Communist regimes; Stalinism
and de-Stalinization; everyday life under Communism; the Hungarian Revolution of 1956, the Prague Spring, and Solidarity; political opposition; culture; and
the revolutions of 1989.

title: Jews in Poland
description: History : Analyses of primary sources (in translation) related to the social, economic and institutional history of the Jews in Poland and their place in the East European Jewish community. Topics include: the Jews during "The Flood'' (1648 - 1667), the communal crisis of the late 17th century, the Frankist movement, and Hasidism.

title: Formation of Chinese Tradition
description: History : An examination of the multiple sources of the Chinese imperial system from the period of the neolithic culture interaction sphere to the fall of the Han dynasty in 220 C.E. Special attention is paid to socio-economic developments as well as to the evolution of philosophy, ideology, and social practice. The sequel to this course is HIST 358.

title: History of Latin America to 1825
description: History : The social, cultural, and economic aspects of Latin America and the Caribbean in the colonial period and the transition to independence.

title: Themes in European History
description: History : Exploration of a theme in the history of Europe.  Topics vary from year to year.

title: History of Consumption in Canada
description: History : History of consumption in Canada since 1600 in relation to subsistence and the early market; modern class and gender relationships; conceptions of citizenship.

title: Habsburg Monarchy, 1618-1918
description: History : History of the central European Habsburg Monarchy from its consolidation in the Thirty Years' War to its demise in the Great War. Topics include: counter-Reformation and the baroque, enlightened absolutism, the partitions of Poland, the revolutions of 1848, the rise of nationalism, and fin-de-siècle society and culture.

title: Themes: British Isles History
description: History : Exploration of a theme in British Isles history.

title: Themes in World History
description: History : Historical phenomena that transcend the boundaries of nation-status and contributed to the long-term development of globalization.

title: History of the Russian Empire
description: History : History of the Russian empire from its formal proclamation by Peter the Great to its eventual collapse in 1917; the rise of the Romanov dynasty, imperial conquest, and the dynamics of imperial Russian society, and the revolutions of 1905 and 1917.

title: Themes in Indian Ocean World History
description: History : Examination of a selected theme or topic in the history of the Indian Ocean World.

title: The Scientific Revolution
description: History : The intellectual and cultural history of science and technology, in Europe and in the wider world, from the time of Leonardo to the time of Newton (c. 1500-c.1700).

title: Themes in Intellectual History
description: History : Examination of a selected theme or subject in intellectual history and/or the history of ideas.

title: History and Sexuality 1
description: History : Antiquity to Early Modern Europe. The cultural meanings and social institutions that create the historical context for sexual behaviours. Possible topics include: Greek homosocial and homosexual culture; sex and citizenship; wives and concubines in the ancient world; Christianity and aestheticism; misogyny and gender in Medieval Europe; adultery and lineage.

title: Indigenous Identities and Nationhood
description: History : This course examines themes in Indigenous history with a particular focus on Indigenous identity formation, articulation, and nationhood. It exposes students to an advanced understanding of the ways in which Indigenous peoples have historically identified themselves and activated their sense of nationhood.

title: Renaissance-Reformation Europe
description:
History : An examination of Western Europe from the late 14th to the end of the 16th century. Topics will include the Renaissance, in and outside Italy, the
Reformations, the religious wars of the 16th century and the Scientific Revolution.

title: History of the Soviet Union
description: History : The history of the Soviet Union from 1917-1991, examining its origins in the collapse of autocracy, early Soviet utopianism, the rise of Stalin, the Second World War, Khrushchev’s reforms, the Cold War and the decline and eventual collapse of the USSR, as well as its legacies in the post-Soviet period.

title: Age of the American Revolution
description: History : Analyzes the origins, contingencies, and outcomes of the American Revolution. Spanning the decades from the 1760s to 1820s, it also seeks to place the Revolution in an Atlantic-wide context and to offer a foundation for studying American institutions.

title: Themes in Modern Chinese History
description: History : Exploration of a theme in Modern Chinese history.

title: History of Yugoslavia
description: History : Origins of the Yugoslav idea in 19th-century national movements; the rise and fall of the interwar Kingdom of Serbs, Croats, and Slovenes; occupation, ethnic cleansing, and partisan warfare during WWII; the evolution of Titoist rule and the interplay between Communism and nationalism; and the violent fragmentation of Yugoslavia after 1989.

title: Themes in Canadian History
description: History : Exploration of a theme in Canadian history.

title: The United States Between the Wars
description: History : The history of the United States from the Great War to the end of the 1940s. Social change and conflict, political conservatism, economic prosperity and the culture of consumption during the 1920s; the consequences of the Great Depression and the New Deal.

title: Women in Europe, 1350-1700
description: History : An introduction to concepts of women and the realities of women's lives in western Europe from the Black Death to ca. 1700. Topics will include marriage and the family, female education and literacy, varieties of spirituality and the emergence of a proto-feminism during the Renaissance.

title: Indigenous Peoples and French
description:
History : Encounters between Indigenous Peoples and French newcomers in Canada and other parts of North America, 16th - 18th century. Through an examination of exploration, Catholic missions, trade, military alliances and colonization, the
course focuses on the motives, outlooks and actions of both Indigenous Peoples and Europeans.

title: History of New France
description: History : Social, political, and cultural history of France's ancien régime settlement colonies in North America. Topics include the nature of the absolutist colonial state and French imperialism; society; family; the Church; gender; and religion.

title: Science and Medicine in Canada
description: History : The social and intellectual history of science and medicine in Canada, from early exploration, through the rise of learned societies, universities and professional organizations, to World War II.

title: France, 1789 to 1914
description: History : A study of the history of France from the Revolution to World War I.

title: Twentieth-Century China
description: History : Examines 20th Century China from the fall of the Qing, through Republican China, the emergence of communism, war with Japan, revolution and civil war, the Cultural Revolution, and later economic reforms.

title: History of Modern Egypt
description: History : Explores the history of Egypt from the 18th Century to today. Topics include: Ottoman Egypt, the impact of French and British Colonialism, Nasserism, Camp David and economic liberalization, and the Egyptian Revolution of 2011.

title: Themes in South Asian History
description: History : Exploration of a theme in the history of South Asia.

title: Canada and the World
description: History : Examines the historical development of Canada and the World from 1867 to the present. Particular emphasis will be placed on key themes in the history of Canada’s international relations including imperialism and race. Attention will also be paid to major global developments such as wars, peace-making and international governance. The course will consider traditional inter-state relations as well as international relations from a non-governmental, grassroots perspective to include migration, development and humanitarianism.

title: Women in Post-Confederation Canada
description: History : This course examines women's contribution to the economic and social development of Canada as well as the changes in the image and status of women. Special emphasis will be on the relationship between women's roles in the private sphere and the public domain.

title: The Chinese Family in History
description: History : Exploration of the Chinese family in history both as an institution - in its religious, legal, economic, political aspects - and as a lived reality.

title: History of Italian Renaissance
description: History : An introduction to the economy, society, politics and intellectual developments in Italy from approximately 1300 to the early 16th century.

title: France, 1914 to the Present
description: History : A study of the history of France from World War I to the present.

title: History and Sexuality 2
description: History : 1700 to the present, with a particular focus on Europe and North America. Possible topics include: patterns of fertility and sexual practice; prostitution; religion and sexuality; the medical and legal construction of sexualities; the rise of sexology; gay liberation movements; queer politics.

title: Greece: From Ottoman to the European Union
description: History : Examines the emergence of a modern nation state in the Balkans out of the Ottoman empire and its evolution until its present status as a member state of the European Union. A story of Greece and Greeks within the broader regional and global context.

title: Science and the Enlightenment
description: History : Explores the relationship between the natural sciences and the eighteenth-century Enlightenment. Examination of works in post-Newtonian science as well as their broader cultural meaning, the history of material practices, the origins of social science, and the role of geography and international context beyond Western Europe.

title: Themes in U.S. History since 1865
description: History : Aspects of American history from the gilded Age through the Cold War era.

title: African Diaspora Post-Emancipation
description:
History : Exploration of the ways that diasporic Africans in the Atlantic World imagined freedom after European empires nominally abolished chattel enslavement in the mid-nineteenth century, including resistance, migrations, mass social movements, trans-Atlantic organizing, as well as imperialism, colonialism, and neo-colonialism from the 
nineteenth century to the contemporary period.

title: History of Montreal
description: History : The history of Montreal from its beginnings to the present day. Montreal's economic, social, cultural and political role within the French and British empires, North America, Canada, and Quebec; the city's  linguistic and ethnic diversity.

title: Women in Europe 1700-2000
description: History : An overview of the history of women in modern continental Europe, focusing on women's changing roles in the family and society at large, in the context of work, family life, education, and culture, and the changing notions of citizenship, femininity, and masculinity.

title: Medicine in the Medieval West
description: History : The history of ideas about the human body, disease and therapeutics and the diverse practices of medicine in western Europe in the Middle Ages (ca. AD 300-1500), with particular attention to their social, intellectual, cultural and religious context.

title: Cultural Diversity in Canada
description: History : Selected topics in cultural diversity, society and the state in 19th, 20th and/or 21st centuries will be explored through discussion of primary and secondary historical sources.

title: China's Middle Empires
description: History : Developments of China's middle empires, ca. 600-1300 CE.  Studies changing international relations, rapid commercialization, religious developments, the rise of the civil service examination system, and ensuing social change.

title: Latin America since 1825
description: History : Themes in the political, economic, and social development of Latin America since the wars of independence.

title: Topics in Canadian Regional History
description: History : Topics in Canadian regional history. Topics will vary by year.

title: Byzantine History and Historiography
description: History : Examines the political, social, cultural, and economic aspects of the 1000-year story of the Eastern Roman Empire, also known as the Byzantine empire, as well as its posterity.

title: Canada 1870-1914
description: History : This course will examine social, economic, political and cultural aspects of Canadian society between 1870 and 1914. Topics covered will include aboriginal peoples, European settlement of the West, provincial rights, the national policy, social reform movements, industrialization, immigration and the rise of cities.

title: Canada 1914-1945
description: History : This course will examine Canada and Canadian society between 1914 and 1945. It will focus on the social, political, economic and cultural impact of the two World Wars and the economic crisis of the 1930s. Among the topics will be Canadian external relations, political and social protest, popular culture, demographic changes and prohibition.

title: China's Early Empires
description: History : Considers China's early imperial period, from ca. 300 BCE to ca. 100 CE, including changing political, social, and economic institutions, court and intellectual life, population management, foreign relations, urban transformations, and textual and material culture.  Introduction to the major historiographical sources covering the period, and to newly excavated texts, artifacts, and sites.

title: Themes in Latin American History
description: History : Exploration of a specific topic in the history of Latin America and the Caribbean, 1492 to the present.

title: Canada since 1945
description: History : Elements of Canada's political, social, economic, and cultural history since World War II. Topics will include constitutional questions, gender and class issues, the role of the state, regionalism, consumer society, the Quiet Revolution, and nationalism in Canada.

title: Greek History: Classical Period
description: History : The Classical period of Greek history, from the end of the Persian wars to the death of Alexandra the Great (479-323 BC).

title: Greek History: Early Greece
description: History : Historical study of the period from the Mycenean Age to the end of the Archaic Age.

title: Topics: Canadian Political History
description: History : Explores a topic related to the political history of Canada.

title: American Civil Rights 1877-1940
description: History : The social, economic, political, and constitutional history of citizenship and civil rights in the United States from the end of Reconstruction through the 1930s. Emphasis on segregation and disfranchisement; immigration restrictions, americanization and national identities; civil rights movements and organizations; women's suffrage; voting rights and representation.

title: Themes in Medieval History
description: History : Explores various aspects of the Middle Ages through thematic approaches. Examines specific issues such as gender, intercultural relations, trade and commerce, diplomatic history, urban development, or religious development in the medieval period, through a variety of sources, including narrative and archival documents, archaeological data, and material culture. Historical methodology in relation to the study of the Middle Ages is emphasized. Topics vary by year.

title: Canadian Labour History
description: History : This course explores themes in labour and working class history in Canada.

title: History of Sexuality in Canada
description: History : Sexuality as theory, culture, and historical experience in Canada from early contact period to the present. Chronological and thematic format. Topics include fertility and its control, prostitution and pornography, sexual repression and liberation in medicine and politics, queer theory and economies of pleasure.

title: Rome: Republic to Empire
description: History : Roman history from the Gracchi to the death of the emperor Nero, 133 BCE to 68 CE. The collapse of the Roman republic, the reorganization of the Roman state under Augustus, and the Roman empire and society under the early emperors.

title: Fall of the Roman Empire
description: History : Transformation of the Roman world, 1st-7th CE. Considers various perspectives and narratives of the decline and fall of the Roman Empire based on historical and material evidence.

title: The United States, 1940-1965
description: History : Major events in politics and international affairs, culture and society, and the economy in the U.S. during and after World War II. Topics include: The War and American society; the first years of the Cold War; economic prosperity and social change; the civil rights movement; Vietnam to 1965.

title: The Medieval Mediterranean
description: History : Thematic history of the Mediterranean during the Medieval period, covering elements of Latin, Byzantine and Islamic civilizations and their interactions.

title: Colonial Africa
description: History : An overview of the history of foreign intervention and anticolonial resistance in 19th and 20th century Africa. Topics include: theories of colonialism, the scramble for Africa, colonialism and disease, indirect rule, labour, nationalism and resistance, and changing gender roles.

title: History of South Africa
description: History : History of South Africa from precolonial times to the present. Topics include: precolonial societies; British and Dutch colonialism; slavery in colonial South Africa; the Zulu kingdom; mining capitalism; the Boer War; Afrikaner nationalism; apartheid; the anti-apartheid struggle; music, religion, and art; challenges of the post-apartheid state.

title: Eighteenth-Century Britain
description: History : Cultural, intellectual, political, economic and social history of Britain and Ireland in the eighteenth century; the era of the creation of the United Kingdom and the rise of a great commercial and imperial power.

title: Nineteenth-Century Britain
description: History : Cultural, intellectual, political, economic and social history of Britain and Ireland in an era of unprecedented economic and cultural change as the United Kingdom became the world's first industrial nation and leading imperial power.

title: Twentieth-Century Britain
description: History : From a range of perspectives, including cultural, intellectual, political, economic and social history, this course examines Britain from the height of its power, through two world wars, the building of a welfare state, the dissolution of Empire and entry into Europe, to the start of the 21st century. consensus, decolonisation, immigration, culture and society, Northern Ireland, Scottish and Welsh nationalism, Thatcherism, the European Union.

title: The First World War
description: History : A world-wide political, social, economic, cultural and military survey, from the origins of the Great War to the Treaty of Versailles.

title: The Second World War
description: History : A world-wide political, social, economic, cultural and military survey, from the Treaty of Versailles to the first years of the Cold War.

title: Topics: African Country Survey
description: History : In depth survey of a single African country (other than South Africa), including the pre-colonial history of the region, colonialism, and post-colonial economic, cultural and political history.

title: Eighteenth-Century France
description: History : The political, social, and cultural history of France, from the accession of Louis XV (1715) to the rise of Napoleon (1799), including the French Revolution.

title: Rise of Rome
description: History : Rome's rise from city-state to world power, 338 - 133 BCE, the nature Roman conquest, and the impact of empire on Roman society.

title: The United States since 1965
description: History : Major events in politics and international affairs, culture and society, and economy in the U.S. since 1965. Topics include: social and political upheaval 1965 - 1975; Vietnam to 1975; conservative politics; Nixon and Watergate; economic change in the 1970s and 1980s; presidential leadership from Carter on.

title: Civil War and Reconstruction
description: History : The causes of the American Civil War; the social, economic, political and military forces that shaped the conflict, attempts to restructure race relations, Southern and American societies after the war.

title: British Revolutions 1603-1714
description: History : English, Scottish and Irish history during the seventeenth and early eighteenth centuries, with a particular focus on the origins and consequences of the regicidal revolution of 1649 and the glorious revolution of 1688.

title: Canada: Ethnicity, Migration
description: History : Immigration, ethnicity and race in Canada in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. Topics will include the migration process, government policy and legislation, urban and rural migration, acculturation, nativism and multiculturalism.

title: Topics in Italian History
description: History : Topics in Italian history.  Topic varies by year.

title: History and Historiography
description: History : The nature and functions of history; changing conceptions of time and of the past; approaches to historical evidence; methods of reconstructing the past; how the discipline of history has changed over time.

title: Ancient Greece, Rome and China
description: History : A comparative analysis of the political cultures of ancient Greece, Rome and China, c. 500 BCE to 500 CE, exploring societal distinctions through topics such as the role of historical traditions, power configurations, public oratory, elite representation, funerary rites and political spaces.

title: Topics: Medieval Culture and Society
description: History : Selected topics in the intellectual and cultural history of the Middle Ages. Emphasis on modern critical approaches to medieval culture, including literature, the supernatural, religious experience.

title: The History of Confucius
description: History : Confucius is inseparable from the idea of China or even East Asia. This course will unpack the manifold legacies of Confucius and his classics in pre-imperial, imperial, and modern China.

title: Topics in Intellectual History
description: History : In depth analysis of a selected subject or topic in intellectual history and/or the history of ideas.

title: Topics: Russian History
description: History : Examination of a selected topic in Russian history from the reign of Peter the Great to the present time.

title: Topics in Ancient History
description: History : An in-depth look at various topics in ancient history.

title: Selected Topics in Indigenous History
description: History : Selected topics in Indigenous history.

title: Topics in Latin American History
description: History : In-depth discussion and research on a circumscribed topic in the history of Latin America and the Caribbean, 1492 to the present.

title: Topics in History of Science
description: History : Specific theme in the history of science, such as scientific instruments, experimental practices, uses of the body, knowledge and museums, scientific institutions, or science and empire.

title: Topics in African History
description: History : In depth examination of a specific topic or individual in African or African diasporic history.

title: Women and Gender in Modern Britain
description: History : Women and gender in modern Britain (1850 on). Topics include early feminist political agitation, including the suffrage movement; working-class women; changing notions of gender, sexuality and women's role; women and empire.

title: British and Irish Nationalisms
description: History : The history of Irish, Scottish, Welsh and English nationalisms in the British context from 1688 to the present.

title: Topics: Atlantic World
description: History : Exploration of a specific theme in Atlantic history, 1500 to 1850.

title: Central America
description: History : The study of historical roots of the regional crisis of the 1980s, with particular attention to Nicaragua, El Salvador and Guatemala.

title: Gender and Sexuality in Modern China
description: History : The history of gender and sexuality in modern China. Topics include Chinese femininities and Chinese masculinities, theories of sexuality, and changing conceptions of gender identity under Confucianism, Western Imperialism, and socialism.

title: Topics in Early Modern Europe
description: History : Varying subjects of topical interest regarding early-modern Europe.

title: Topics: Migration and Ethnicity
description: History : The study of various topics and themes in the area of migration, ethnicity and race in Canada. Topics vary from year to year.

title: Gender, Sexuality and Medicine
description: History : Gender, sexuality, and medicine since the colonial era, with a focus on North American experience. Topics will include reproductive medicine (puberty, childbirth, fertility control, menopause), changing perceptions of men's and women's health needs and risks, and ideas about sexual behaviour and identity.

title: Global Food History
description: History : A history of food and drink in global history. Topics include: feasts and famines; the exchange of foodstuffs and drinking habits between cultures, especially the early modern 'Columbian exchange'; the history of civilizing processes (e.g, table manners); the origins of the restaurant and the making of modern food systems.

title: Topics: British Cultural History
description: History : Selected topics in intellectual and cultural history of Britain and Ireland, focusing on discussion of primary texts.

title: The Hasidic Movement
description: History : A historical examination of the history of the Hasidic Movement from its beginnings in 18th-century Poland to the present. Although emphasis will be placed on the social history of the movement, doctrinal developments will be examined as well.

title: Topics: History of the Book
description: History : The theory and the practice of using books, manuscripts, periodicals as well as other communicative media. Topics may include literacy and orality; the print revolution; censorship; readers and reading practices; newspapers and journalism; the origins of scientific persuasion and intellectual property rights.

title: Topics: Gender/Feminist Histories
description: History : An intensive study of selected aspects related to the history of gender, feminism, and sexuality.

title: Topics in Modern Medicine
description: History : Selected topics in the history of medicine in the 19th, 20th and/or 21st centuries will be explored through discussion of primary and secondary historical sources.

title: Topics in U.S. History
description: History : Various topics in United States history.

title: Topics in Labour History
description: History : Exploration of selected themes in labour and working-class history from diverse geographical and transnational perspectives.

title: British Queer History
description: History : An investigation of the changing historical construction of "deviant" and "normal" sexualities in Britain since 1700, and how queer women and men discovered ways of surviving and perhaps even flourishing in the face of persecution and hostility from the state, the churches and the medical profession.

title: British North America 1760-1867
description: History : This course will study the social-cultural and political development of British North American colonies.

title: Topics in South Asian History
description: History : In-depth discussion and research on a topic in the history of South Asia.

title: Topics: European History
description: History : An in-depth look at particular aspects of European history.

title: Topics: Issues in Canadian History
description: History : A discussion-based, advanced intensive study of selected aspects of Canadian history.

title: Topics in Cold War History
description: History : One large aspect of Cold War, either thematic or regional, will be explored.

title: History of Women in China
description: History : This course examines the changing roles of women in traditional and modern China. Topics include political, social, and legal status, sexuality and medicine, religion and culture.

title: Fiction and History
description: History : This course examines why and how books are classified as fiction or history. Topics include: social expectations and uses of literature; evidence and verification; the author as authority. Readings include history and fiction from various historical periods, and relevant scholarship.

title: Topics: Culture and Ritual in China
description: History : An examination of selected aspects of the cultural and intellectual life of China. Topics vary from year to year, but include the history of popular religion, Chinese science and medicine, the esoteric arts including divination practices, law, and the influence of ideas in the production of Chinese culture.

title: Asian Diaspora: Chinese Overseas
description: History : The contexts and causes of Chinese emigration; historical patterns of migration; Overseas Chinese communities on five continents, with emphasis on Southeast Asia and North America; alienation and identity in Chinatown; relations between the Overseas Chinese and China.

title: Topics: Modern Japan
description: History : An intensive study of selected aspects related to the history of modern Japan.

title: Late Imperial China
description: History : An introduction to the social and economic history of Late Imperial China, focusing on the Ming and early to mid Qing Dynasties (1368 - 1800), and current interpretations thereof. Was this a discrete period in Chinese history? If so, why.

title: Topics in Middle East History
description: History : Examination of a selected topic in the history of the modern Middle East from the late 19th century to the present.

title: Medicine in the Ancient World
description: History : The evolution of ideas about the human body, disease, and therapeutics, and the diverse practices of medicine in Graeco-Roman antiquity (ca 800BC - ca 600CE), with particular attention given to their social, political, cultural and religious context.

title: Ancient History Methods
description: History : Different methods and strategies employed by Ancient historians, including numismatics, epigraphy, and papyrology.

title: Topics in Pre-Modern Medicine
description: History : The history of the evolution of ideas about the human body, disease and therapeutics and the diverse practices of medicine prior to the advent of modern clinical and laboratory medicine in the 19th c., with particular attention to social, political, cultural and religious context.

title: History of Revolution in Europe
description:
History : The evolution of the concept and phenomenon of revolution from the 1640s in England to 1989 in eastern Europe. How the experiences of 1789, 1848, and
1917 changed the theory and practice of revolution.

title: Marxist Theory
description: History : Themes in Marxist theory and historiography, from the mid-19th century to the present moment. Topics will include the global intellectual history of Marxism in political and economic thought, diverse Marxisms around the world, contemporary developments in Marxist theory, historical analysis and historiography.

title: Topics in Medical History
description: History : This course explores different topics in medical history. Topics to be explored include the role of medicine from ancient to modern times.

title: Europe Since 1989
description: History : Though the European continent has changed beyond recognition since 1989, historians are only just beginning to turn their attention to this most contemporary of European epochs. This course therefore provides students an opportunity to conduct ground-breaking research, informed by readings and seminar discussions on such topics as Thatcherism, the round tables and revolutions of 1989, war and genocide in Yugoslavia, European integration, the fall and rise of Russia, technological change, and related transformations of society and culture. The course provides training in methods appropriate for research on contemporary history, and though it does not neglect great powers, it is well suited to students interested in Europe’s small countries.

title: Alexander and Hellenistic World
description:
History : The history and culture of the Hellenistic period, from the Age of Alexander to the rise of the successor kingdoms and their interactions with Rome; discusses the
development of a new sense of globality and its impact on the local horizon of cities across the Mediterranean and beyond.

title: History of European Education
description: History : A history of school and schooling within the European context since the invention of print. Topics include: passage from private to public practices; modern statehood and education; school and social mobility; school and the civilizing mission; student mobility; universities and the specialization of academic disciplines; Europe and the globalization of the educational field.

title: Topics: Roman History
description: History : In-depth examination of a selected topic, theme, or period of ancient Roman history.

title: Pre-modern Chinese Law and Society
description: History : The history of Chinese law and society from early pre-imperial to late imperial times. Themes include the philosophical basis of Chinese law; development of different forms of legislation; practice of pre-modern law; law and social and political change; military law; legal cases translated from primary sources.

title: Democracy and Society in India
description: History : A specialized in-depth historical survey of issues and problems in the transformation of India towards democracy in the post-colonial era.

title: History of Bangladesh and Pakistan
description: History : Examines social and political histories of Pakistan and Bangladesh from 1947 to present with attention to the roles of Islam, ethnicity and nationalism.

title: Global History of Coffee
description: History : The history of coffee and coffeehouses from the discovery of coffee in the late medieval Ottoman empire until the present day. Topics include the putative 'golden age' of coffeehouse culture in the early modern era, the transformations of the coffeehouse in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, the development of a modern consumer society, and forms of public association and communication often described as the bourgeois public sphere.

title: Emotions History of Early Modern Europe
description: History : Readings and research on the history of emotions in the early modern era (c.  1450 – c. 1800). Introduction to the topic with a focus on how historians have studied the emotional life of Europeans between the age of renaissance and reformation and the French Revolution, including selected studies of the medieval and modern eras.

title: Independent Research
description:
History : Exceptionally, and under the direction of a member of staff, advanced and highly qualified students who have an extensive background in the proposed area
of study, may pursue this independent study.

title: Internship: History
description: History : Internship with an approved host institution or organization.

title: Topics in Modern European History
description: History : Advanced topics in modern European history. Topics will vary by year. The course has a substantial research component.

title: Topics: World History
description: History : Selected topics in world history.

title: Topics: The British Empire
description: History : Topics in the history of British formal and informal imperialism and the colonial encounter from the eighteenth to the twentieth centuries.

title: Theory for Historical Studies
description: History : Approaches to the interpretation and understanding of historical evidence which are outside the traditional historical discipline - reading of central texts in, for example, psychoanalytic theory, gender theory, or literary criticism and exercises in the use of these theories for historical research.

title: Topics in Early Modern History
description: History : Readings and research on a selected topic in early modern history.

title: The Art of War in China
description: History : A study of the historical development of military theory and practice from earliest times to 1911 from a variety of perspectives, technological, scientific, social, and cultural.

title: European Intellectual History
description: History : Study of selected topics in European intellectual and/or cultural history.

title: Environmental History of Latin America
description:
History : Human-nature interactions over different scales of time in Latin America (with an emphasis on neo-tropical environments) and the application of the historical perspective to contemporary environmental issues, including historiography and
methodology; cultures of environmental knowledge.

title: History of Emotions
description: History : Readings and research on the history of emotions, with focus on how historians have studied the emotional life of the past. Particular attention to the various ways emotion has been conceived in the past and the historical methodologies used to study emotional experiences.

title: Topics in Chinese History
description: History : Exploration of a theme in Chinese history

title: Topics: Canadian International History
description: History : Explores the field of international history and Canada's particular version of it. Examines the artificial divide between national and international history; tracing how race, gender, class, colonialism and imperialism shaped the country's foundations as well as its evolving relationship with developments in the international sphere. Seminar readings and discussions focus on historiographical developments in the study of international history and how this has affected understandings of Canada and its place in the world.

title: Women, Work and Family in Global History
description: History : The shifting historical context of female labour and family in selected western and non-western countries; the interaction between labour and gender relations with special focus on women's experiences on the shop floor and in the family.

title: Women and War
description: History : Examines the impact of war on individuals, families and societies. Studies the experiences of women and children in exile, mass persecutions, and punishments associated with social unrest, revolution or wars during twentieth century.

title: Topics: Indian Ocean World History
description: History : This course studies pivotal topics in Indian Ocean World (IOW) history. Topics may include (i) the rise and development of the IOW global economy; (ii) The Swahili Civilisation and the IOW; (iii) Islam and the IOW; (iv) Imperialism in the IOW; (v) IOW Slavery and Slave Trades; (vi) History of Madagascar.

title: Indian Ocean World Slave Trade
description: History : The origins, structure and impact of the Indian Ocean World slave trade from early times to the present day. Enslavement, the trading structure, slave functions, reactions to slavery, emancipation and 'slave' diaspora. Comparisons will be made to the Atlantic slave system.

title: U.S. Foreign Relations
description: History : The history and historiography, approaches and interpretations, of American foreign relations from the pre-Revolutionary era to the present.

title: History and Biography
description: History : Biography is one of the oldest and most popular historical genres. This course examines the relationship between biographical life writing and historical analysis. Readings include exemplary works of both popular and scholarly biography as well as discussions of biographical research methods. The seminar is designed to prepare students to write their own biographical essay based on original research.

title: 1 Ancient History: Seminar
description: History : Topics in ancient Mediterranean history, focusing on Greek and/or Roman society.

title: 2 Ancient History: Seminar
description: History : Topics in ancient Mediterranean history, focusing on Greek and/or Roman society.

title: International Relations: Seminar
description: History : Readings on and discussion of a theme in the history of international relations.

title: 1 International Relations: Seminar
description: History : Readings on and discussion of a theme in the history of international relations.

title: 2 International Relations Seminar
description: History : Readings on and discussion of a theme in the history of international relations.

title: 1 Seminar: Medieval History
description: History : Readings and discussion on a selected topic in Medieval history.

title: 2 Seminar: Medieval History
description: History : Readings and discussion on a selected topic in Medieval history.

title: 1 Seminar: Colonial America
description: History : Readings in and discussion of a theme in the history of Colonial America.

title: 2 Seminar: Colonial America
description: History : Readings in and discussion of a theme in the history of Colonial America.

title: Modern Medicine: Seminar
description: History : The emergence of scientific medicine, medical professionalization, the development of public health and the process of medical specialization since 1700.

title: Modern Medicine: Research
description: History : Supervised design, research, writing, and discussion of a major research paper on a theme in the history of modern medicine since 1700.

title: World History: Seminar
description: History : Readings on and discussion of a theme in world history.

title: 1 World History: Seminar
description: History : Readings on and discussion of a theme in world history.

title: 2 World History: Seminar
description: History : Readings on and discussion of a theme in world history.

title: 1 Seminar: Latin American History
description: History : Exploration of a selected topic in Latin America history.

title: 2 Seminar: Latin American History
description: History : See HIST 564D1 for course description.

title: Modern Britain: Seminar
description: History : Readings in and discussion of a theme in Modern British history.

title: 1 Modern Britain: Seminar
description: History : Readings in and discussion of a theme in Modern British history.

title: 2 Modern Britain: Seminar
description: History : Readings in and discussion of a theme in Modern British history.

title: 1 Seminar: Medieval Medicine
description: History : Models of the body, disease and medical intervention current in western Europe between 400 and 1500 AD will be examined through analysis of primary sources in translation, and modern historical scholarship.

title: 2 Seminar: Medieval Medicine
description: History : Models of the body, disease and medical intervention current in western Europe between 400 and 1500 AD will be examined through analysis of primary sources in translation, and modern historical scholarship. The sequel to this course is HIST 496.

title: 1 Topics in Chinese History
description: History : A research seminar on aspects of Chinese history from early time to the present, with emphasis on social history.

title: 2 Topics in Chinese History
description: History : See HIST 568D1 for course description.

title: 1 Topics: Modern French History
description: History : An examination of select topics in modern French history and European intellectual history as it relates to France.

title: 2 Topics: Modern French History
description: History : See HIST 488D1 for course description.

title: 1 Topics: Historical Interpretation
description: History : Topics in historical interpretation.  Topic varies by year.

title: 2 Topics: Historical Interpretation
description: History : See HIST 570D1 for course description.

title: 1 Seminar: Italian Renaissance
description: History : Seminar on the Italian renaissance.

title: 2 Seminar: Italian Renaissance
description: History : See HIST 571D1 for course description.

title: 1 Seminar in Jewish History
description: History : Seminar in Jewish history.  Topic varies by year.

title: 2 Seminar in Jewish History
description: History : Seminar in Jewish history.  Topic varies by year.

title: 1 Seminar on Central Europe
description: History : A research seminar on selected topics in the history of central Europe, defined as the Holy Roman Empire, the Habsburg Monarchy, and their successor states. Topics vary by year.

title: 2 Seminar on Central Europe
description: History : See HIST 573D1 for course description.

title: 1 Topics in Comparative History
description: History : Topics in comparative history.  Topic varies by year.

title: 2 Topics in Comparative History
description: History : See HIST 574D1 for course description.

title: 1 Topics: Germany
description: History : A study of topics on Germany.  Topic vary by year.

title: 2 Topics: Germany
description: History : See HIST 575D1 for course description.

title: 1 Seminar: Topics in Russian History
description: History : Topics in Russian history.  Topic varies by year.

title: 2 Seminar: Topics in Russian History
description: History : See HIST 576D1 for course description.

title: 1 Seminar: Antiquity to Reformation
description: History : Seminar on topics from Antiquity to Reformation.

title: 2 Seminar: Antiquity to Reformation
description: History : See HIST 577D1 for course description.

title: 1 Seminar in Japanese History
description: History : Particular attention will be paid to Japanese responses to the impact of Western culture from the sixteenth century, and to aspects of Japanese intellectual history.

title: 2 Seminar in Japanese History
description: History : See HIST 578D1 for course description.

title: 1 Seminar: African History
description: History : Readings in and discussion of a theme in African history.

title: 2 Seminar: African History
description: History : See HIST 579D1 for course description.

title: 1 European and Native-American Encounters
description: History : This seminar will examine European and Native encounters throughout the Americas, from the late 15th century to the mid-nineteenth century. The aim is to introduce students to key primary sources related to contact, and to the methods used to interpret them.

title: 2 European and Native-American Encounters
description: History : See HIST 580D1 for course description.

title: 1 Seminar: History of Law and Society in Canada
description: History : Research seminar in the history of practices, ideas, philosophies of law in Canada according to different political, social, and cultural traditions, including Indigenous traditions, New France, Quebec civil law, British and Canadian criminal and civil law, Charter and Rights; also legal and historiographical methods, reasoning, and standards of evidence.

title: 2 Seminar: History of Law and Society in Canada
description: History : See HIST 585D1 for course description.

title: 1 Canada: Diasporas and the State
description: History : Explores themes in the history of migration and international diasporas, and state and societal responses to immigrants

title: 2 Canada: Diasporas and the State
description: History : Explores themes in the history of migration and international diasporas, and state and societal responses to immigrants

title: 1 Topics: Canadian Social History
description: History : Topics in Canadian social history.  Topic varies by year.

title: 2 Topics: Canadian Social History
description: History : See HIST 587D1 for course description.

title: 1 History of Montreal
description: History : A history of Montreal.

title: 2 History of Montreal
